user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_QueueDelete_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_QueueDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32                            return_code;
    OS_impl_queue_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_queue_table, *token);

    /* Try to delete and unlink the queue */
    if (mq_close(impl->id) != 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("OS_QueueDelete Error during mq_close(). errno = %d (%s)\n", errno, strerror(errno));
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_QueueDelete_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_queue_internal_record_t OS_impl_queue_table[OS_MAX_QUEUES]
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
typedef struct
{
    mqd_t id;
} OS_impl_queue_internal_record_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No fragments that modify the function parameter were found. Reasons:
- There is no assignment to the parameter identifier token (no statements like token = ...).
- The only use of token is as *token in the macro call OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_queue_table, *token). That dereferences the pointer to access the referenced object; modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter is permitted by the rule, and here no modification occurs (only read access to obtain the index).
- The macro expansion effectively calls OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(*token)), which yields the same pointer value as token; taking the address of *token does not change the pointer parameter itself.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken accepts a const OS_object_token_t * and only reads token->obj_idx (no modification of the pointer or the object).
- No other uses in the function alter token (no pointer arithmetic, no reassignment, no passing of &token to a function that could modify it).
- The mq_close(impl->id) call only uses impl (derived from table lookup) and does not modify the token parameter.

Therefore there are no code fragments in the provided function that warrant investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
